title: Estimated Ethanol (and Toxic Alcohol) Serum Concentration Based on Ingestion
description: Predicts ethanol and toxic alcohol serum concentration based on amount ingested and patient weight using volume of distribution principles.

parameters.name: amount_ingested_ml
parameters.description: Amount of pure alcohol ingested in milliliters

parameters.name: alcohol_percentage
parameters.description: Percentage of alcohol in the consumed beverage (optional, defaults to 100% for pure alcohol)

result.name: serum_concentration
result.description: Estimated serum concentration and clinical interpretation

ranges.interpretation: Mild intoxication. May cause euphoria, decreased inhibition, and mild impairment of judgment and coordination.
Moderate intoxication. Significant impairment of motor control, reaction time, and judgment. Legal intoxication in most jurisdictions.
Severe intoxication. Risk of respiratory depression, coma, and death. Requires immediate medical attention.
Life-threatening alcohol poisoning. High risk of respiratory failure, coma, and death. Requires emergency intervention.
Methanol is highly toxic. Serum levels ≥20 mg/dL require immediate treatment with fomepizole or ethanol and hemodialysis.
Ethylene glycol is highly toxic. Serum levels ≥20 mg/dL require immediate treatment with fomepizole or ethanol and hemodialysis.

references: Baselt RC. Disposition of toxic drugs and chemicals in man. 11th ed. Seal Beach, CA: Biomedical Publications; 2017.

Barceloux DG, Bond GR, Krenzelok EP, Cooper H, Vale JA; American Academy of Clinical Toxicology Ad Hoc Committee on the Treatment Guidelines for Methanol Poisoning. American Academy of Clinical Toxicology practice guidelines on the treatment of methanol poisoning. J Toxicol Clin Toxicol. 2002;40(4):415-46. doi: 10.1081/clt-120006745.

Brent J, McMartin K, Phillips S, Aaron C, Kulig K; Methylpyrazole for Toxic Alcohols Study Group. Fomepizole for the treatment of methanol poisoning. N Engl J Med. 2001 Feb 8;344(6):424-9. doi: 10.1056/NEJM200102083440605.

Watson WA, Litovitz TL, Rodgers GC Jr, Klein-Schwartz W, Reid N, Youniss J, et al. 2004 annual report of the American Association of Poison Control Centers Toxic Exposure Surveillance System. Am J Emerg Med. 2005 Sep;23(5):589-666. doi: 10.1016/j.ajem.2005.05.001.
formula: Serum Concentration (mg/L) = [Amount ingested (mg)] / [Volume of distribution (0.6 L/kg) × Weight (kg)]
notes: Uses standard volume of distribution of 0.6 L/kg
Actual serum concentrations may vary significantly based on individual factors
Does not account for time since ingestion
Methanol and ethylene glycol levels ≥20 mg/dL require immediate treatment
Ethanol levels >300 mg/dL are potentially fatal
Always obtain actual serum levels when available
Use in conjunction with clinical assessment and osmolar gap
Isopropanol is less toxic but can cause significant CNS depression
